comments.commentBody: OK - here is a simpler requirement for a solution (all 9 sums unique and spanning 16 to 24). Notice that if you consider a sum and a sum 2 steps away, you are adding almost the same group of four except one old member is lost and one new member is gained. Furthermore, those two members are adjacent. Now if you hop around the star in steps of two you will land on all nine points before repeating. So the successive pairwise differences in the 9 numbers of a solution, accumulated one by one, must step uniquely through a range of nine consecutive integers. It's like telling someone on a ladder to step up 1 rung, up 2, up 5, down 1, down 5, etc., such that he steps once on nine adjacent rungs.  So that's a simple requirement for a solution, if not yet a guide to finding them all.
The comment above is wrong. Ignore. (Two members change, not one, and also the property I cite is true of all arrangements of nine numbers)

The post above is all wrong. Please ignore. (Two member change as you hop two steps around, not one.) Also having differences land you on 9 unique steps is an inherent property of any string of nine digits.

Mark:

That "right wing nut", Giuliani, happens to be a former NYC mayor who did a terrific job dealing with crime. NYC became a much safer city after he took office.

It was di Blasio who said Giuliani "didn't get it", which was a pretty ignorant statement considering the significant drop in the murder rate -- particular in black homicides -- under Giuliani.

It was di Blasio who didn't really get it and is only now starting to realize what it means to lead a major city with a large police department.

I'm in Playa del Carmen as I write this-down the road about 40 miles from Cancun.  Sadly, the once pristine blue-green water and verdent green jungle has given way to honky tonk billboards, blaring disco music and a beach crammed full of American, Mexican and some Europeans.  Earlier, today I was in Akumal-a place I was mesmorized with 30 years ago. Today, after struggling to park and trudging several hundred yards through a poorly planned and constructed mish mash of stores and half baked development schemes, we reached a Coney Island packed beach.  Progress?  I don't think so. Employment? Yes.  I've enjoyed my visits to Cuba and am thrilled about the opportunities to open up their rich, complex society.  I just hope they can manage it and not follow in the Mexican model.  I've always believed that the easiest and fastest way for the US Govenment to effect change in Cuba was to legalize American tourism.  It'd be over in 5 minutes.

R.Will - There is a lot of misinformation that football generates profit for the university and funds other programs. Many reports suggest that this is not true. Most programs that show "profit" usually use funny accounting techniques to justify the programs. Barring a handful of universities, most football programs take away more money than the revenue they generate.

Another big cost is the distraction it generates among students and the associated opportunity cost. Even the athletes themselves get virtually no education and are indentured servants.

"However, I believe that Michigan's overwhelming emphasis placed on football by its administration will eventually hurt its academic standing -- not this year or next, but down the road."

Sure, after 135 years of football, the clock is ticking on the school's demise. I'll check back in with you in the year 2140 to see where we are. In the meantime, the endowment has doubled in the last 10 years. The research dollar volume has doubled in the last 10 years as well. The student teacher ratio is down from 17:1 to 15:1 over the same period. Average board scores and GPA are up. But yes, the 2% of the budget which is football will deform the other 98%.

"This hire shows that Board of Regents has made the school a football factory first and foremost."

The forum rules may not allow this sort of commentation, but your comment is rank stupidity. The Regents vote on many billions every year. Voting a huge contract for a guy who supports a huge revenue and headcount base says nothing about the academic side of the house. Michigan is one of the few schools which can do it all at a high level of quality. Your false dichotomy presupposes that that duality cannot obtain, and that is demonstrably and historically false.

"The point is that it is morally wrong - shamefully wrong - values all messed up wrong - for a public institution that pays no taxes, and that receives all the benefits of tax deductible donations, and whose core mission is public education, to pay this kind of money for a football coach. It is simply immoral."

I agree that it is morally wrong for the state of Michigan to spend more on prisons than on universities. I agree that it was wrong for the state to cut the annual UM grant from $1.3Bln to $.3Bln. I don't agree that it is wrong to fund Title IX with football. I don't agree that it is wrong to provide full scholarships to 400+ student-athletes most of whom are NOT in the revenue sports and many of whom earn respected credentials in biology, chemistry architecture.

My take is that you don't understand the funding challenges the university has faced or how it has closed budgetary shortfalls during a decline in the state GDP or how it has benefited the thousands of scholarship athletes who have passed through Michigan on the way to their ultimate careers.

I like Mr. Bharara...but the Democratic machine of which he is soundly a part (former aide to Senator Schumer who nominated him for his job)...has known about the corruption at ER Housing Corporation for years and years.

It is now, when the tides of demographics are shifting, and in the wake of whatever progressive movement has even temporarily surfaced, when Silver's power base is fading....only now, could this possibly happen.

Trust me, Bharara is no wonder boy.

It is the confluence of time, shifting demographics and the ability to "read" the future which makes this expose and potential law suit possible.

This is exactly the kind of corruption issue that the Moreland Commission was designed to investigate, but the governor looked upon it as merely a political bargaining chip and pulled the plug. Especially as a former attorney general, Mr. Cuomo ought to be ashamed of himself.

Fortunately for the citizens of New York State, the U.S. attorney saw it for what it should have been all along: the first layer of the onion. So, by all means, peel away, Mr. Bharara, peel away.

The toxic vapors emanating from Albany are enough to make a grown person cry, but it's reassuring to know that an incorruptible federal prosecutor is methodically working toward a day when we can wipe them away, at least as far as our most powerful legislator is concerned.

The way it works is that the members of the majority party in the House elect a speaker. The speaker has the power to call (or not call) a legislator's legislation out of committee. If you are seen as a threat to the speaker or directly oppose him, your career is dead. The speaker also has political jobs to offer (patronage) to buy loyalty, and campaign cash and workers to lift supporters or crush opponents.

The only way to dislodge a speaker is by turning the house over to the other party. The NY State assembly is 70% democrat, 30% republican.
Therein lies the problem; a Democratic dominated legislature.

Cuomo was not re-elected by a landslide. In fact, his numbers were shocking low against Ms. Teachout, a virtually unknown candidate, in the primary and against a no name Republican in the general election.

Silver and Cuomo discussed here almost equality - and yet Cuomo was re-elected in a landslide and Silver is deemed unbeatable. I am writing from fly-over land - but why not just vote for someone else? or why not just vote, period? I have read so many comments about de Blasio (not here), too - same thing. Don't New Yorkers, state or city, vote? These comments make it all seem so inevitable - and yet these are ALL elected officials....
It hasn't exactly been a well-kept secret that Mr. Silver's "extra-curricular" activities were of a strictly charitable nature...Another Albany pol cast into the light of transparency.

The picture caption states "Sheldon Silver, a Democrat,..."
Just saying...

Maybe instead of all your over the top
Hyperbole they just disagree with de Blasio's attitude towards police.
Nice idea but the NYPD commanders  do not care.

I would photograph, list, log and and identify every single uniformed cop with back turned on the mayor (or other elected official). Every civilian complaint review board should have the badge numbers of these (rogue?) cops and mark each and every one of the scoundrel cops now because they are the said ones, with lousy attitudes, who feel so entitled to bully and kill the taxpayers that cut their paychecks. These are the cops who feel they have license to maim, injure and use unbridled deadly force to murder innocent citizens. Every station commander should know that we the citizens of the city have tagged, marked these disrespectful cops and have eyes on them. Each of their work files should be marked for this disrespectful conduct and and they should suffer immediate consequences (upto and including termination), especially the rookies just graduating. How dare they!?
Take all their badge numbers and their badges and guns if they dont fall in line immediately and behave.
Public servants with guns and badges need to conduct themselves with more courtesy, professionalism and respect. Shed the uniform, badge and gun if you can not honor the code and the public.

I admire the sentiment of the statement you shared, but the cruel reality is that employers - be they individuals or institutions - must also comply with the basic principles of society as we ourselves are bound. When I consider the transgressions committed by people from Ivan Boesky to Bernard Madoff and organizations the likes of Enron and WorldCom, I question Heaven's call to unconditional loyalty. Ben Franklin had a more moderate approach to dealing the uncertainties of mankind when he offered "Believe none of what you hear and only half of what you see".
Patrick Lynch is an actual NYPD officer snd needs to be fired fortwith. Lynch is the epitome of what a cop should not be.
Patrick Lynch is a disgrace.  He should be banned.

and Elke

Carlo POnti was married to Sophia LOren (another POOL/LOOP combo).
YENS of CANOODLEs with Miss Loren were IN many male MINDs- j'ACCUSE nobody ....Is that why ETNA smokes?

I'm sorry, I would not bet my money on your pride.  If i remember, in all our sophistication and competency we had less than a two dozen guys armed with a few $3 box cutters instantly kill 3000 people and make several trillions of dollars in subsequential damages (wars in Iraq and Afganistan included).
Sadly the airline disappearances remain unsolved.
@C Mepriser: It may seem that way but, again, a quick use of Google shows it not to be so. There have been 12 school shootings in the US in 2014.
Sadly, a Malaysian airline disappearance seems as common as a school shooting in the USA.

If one is really looking for a cell phone then its all true. But, here we are looking for an entire A-320, filled with 166 people, carrying 166+ cell phones, bags, cargo etc. and nothing can be found. The airplane (and crew) might know where they are precisely, but is that information being transmitted to the ground continuously? If it really is, then precisely going to the coordinates where the plane was seconds before it disintegrated and fell from the sky should show some debris surely.
I'm not sure I want another fire hazard on board every jetliner when events like this happen once every (guess)  hundreds of thousands or more flights?

To NoBigDeal of Washington DC: apparently, you also have No Big Deal of knowledge, and No Big Deal of courage, when you fear even to use your real name.
Buy me the tickets, and I will be happy and honored to sit beside any of the Ebola fighters on their return from Africa. They are no risk to America, ignorance and hysteria are the real risk.
It's cowardly hysteria-mongers who scare me.
Sounds like he is correct for a change!!!

Good questions.  It's possible that further discussion with the villagers, which is not transcribed here, has led scientists to recognize those five patients died from Lassa fever instead.  Lassa is endemic, and sometimes mild.  But I am a survivor of the severe, hemorrhagic form of Lassa, and it can be extremely difficult to distinguish hemorrhagic Lassa from hemorrhagic Ebola.  However, Lassa often leaves different sequelae, like sensorineural hearing loss.  And also, Lassa and Ebola can be distinguished by serologic testing of survivors and of the dead.  But if a hemorrhagic Lassa patient and a hemorrhagic Ebola patient both presented at the most sophisticated American hospital, no one could tell the difference without running tests.  The symptoms, at the peak of morbidity, are often identical.

The reason they are unanswered - at the present time - should be pretty obvious. They don't know themselves nor have they the time - given what is going on - to find out for certain. I don't like the tone and innuendo of your article when you read between the lines. This is not a conspiracy, you know

All: Thanks for reading and writing. Speculation about how Emile became infected was a bit beyond the bounds of our story, but Donald McNeill reports on the latest here:

http://www.nytimes.com/2014/12/31/health/source-of-ebola-outbreak-might-...

The article leaves many questions about patient zero unanswered.

Do the scientists have a theory about how this one year old caught Ebola? Was he out playing with the bat dung?

The scientists assert this child is patient zero, yet the article suggests the villagers may be thinking otherwise.

First, the father of patient zero claims the village is killing his family. It would seem that he would only say that if others in the village had died before his son, and they infected his son.

And this seems to be suggested by the list of of those who were first sickened with Ebola. The caption on the image says "A list of the people suspected to have died of Ebola in and around the village of Meliandou, Guinea, during the current outbreak. The list, transcribed by a resident of Meliandou, begins with 1-year-old Emile Ouamouno, believed to be Patient Zero of the outbreak."

But the caption writer seems not to have looked closely at the list. The first 19 patients died in 2014 and begin with patient zero. But then there is a line, and five patients are listed who died in the village between June and September 2013. Who are these patients? And why has the villager listed them? And what do the scientists think of these patients? And if the villagers believe that these also died of Ebola...then how did the virus persist between September and December when little Emile, patient Zero, caught the virus?

Very curious to hear the current scientific thinking on this.

A tough slog, largely because of the raft of neologisms.  Some were nice rewards for the effort, but WAITRON??  WAITER has no gender, any more than ACTOR.  Just avoid the sexist -ESS.  I can appreciate that a WAITRON might server a PATRON (another word that is gender-neutral unless one insists on PATRONESS), but SERIOUSLY?

Bill:

Limbaugh is a right wing talk show host. He is one man, albeit with a huge following. There is no "orchestration". Just his voice being broadcasted.

If you want to see orchestration, look at Sharpton's actions. There you'll find White House meetings and very close ties to Mayor di Blasio. His events usually involve people being paid and bused into locations to protest.

That's orchestration.
Hey .. would you encourage your child to become cop? If not,  don't complain about the people who do.
